content_1: . Highly pathogenic H5N1 broke out in a village in Prey Veng province on April 22. The village was home to 1167 chickens and ducks; 903 died and the rest were culled to prevent the spread of the disease. Samples tested by the National Veterinary Research Institute and Pasteur Institute of Cambodia were positive for H5N1. The National Veterinary Research Institute (NaVRI) of the Department of Animal Health and Production conducted an investigation in the village from 20 to 23 April 2010, but the results were inconclusive. Officials have implemented measures to control the disease, including movement control inside the country and disinfection of the infected premises.
content_2: . Officials of the Agricultural Ministry are investigating the deaths of two chickens at a petting zoo in Kibbutz Ein Gedi to find out if they were caused by avian flu. Test results have been inconclusive, but the Ministry decided to cull the fowl on the kibbutz as a precaution.
content_3: . A four-year-old girl from Riau province died on April 31 from H5N1. (NOTE: date corrected from last weekâ€™s report).Doctors are still awaiting test results for three suspected bird flu patients. They all had contact with dead poultry before developing symptoms and may have been infected from the same source.
